Ian, can you explain further #2?  What do you mean by "leaves some 
convent=
ions unspecified?"  As long as you know the node(s) being 
connected and ke=
ep track of them as NEAT normally does anyway, why 
is this issue specific =
to recurrent connections?  Or maybe I just 
don't know what's meant by an "=
unspecified convention?"  I think 
maybe what you're saying is that what is=
 considered recurrent in 
some individuals may not deserve that designation=
 in others, but I'm 
not certain.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Ba=
dcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
>
> At 15:23 14/11/2005, you wrote:
> >I thin=
k I solved this the following trivial way;
> >
> >Input nodes are labeled d=
epth=3D0, outputnodes are labeled depth=3D1. 
When a
> >connection is split=
, it's labeled depth=3D
(parent1.depth+parent2.depth)/2.
> >
> >Since split=
ting connections is the only way to introduce new 
nodes, all
> >nodes shou=
ld be labeled by the depth they were created at.
> >
> >to prevent recurren=
t connecitons, don't connect a node to a node 
with a
> >lower depth.
> >
>=
 >Seems to work for me and executes in linear time?
> >
> >Am I missing som=
ething really complicated here?
> 
> Hi Mattias,
> 
>          I don't thin=
k you are missing anything.  I think 
basically 
> we reached the conclusio=
n that there are two families of algorithm 
for this:
> 
> 1) some sort of =
arbitrary, or average (as you do) or incremental 
(as 
> I do) parameter is=
 assigned to each node, and all connections 
formed 
> must obey the direct=
ion of this parameter (say lower to higher).
> 
> 2) analyse the network to=
 see if recurrence is being formed and 
> forbid the connection if it is no=
t
> 
> The pros and cons are:
> 
> (1) is faster than (2)
> 
> (1) will not=
 connect some valid topologies - I believe it can make 
> any topology, but=
 some of them in can not assemble from every 
valid precursor
> 
> (2) leav=
es some "conventions" undefined, e.g. nodes which are 
neither 
> up- nor d=
own-stream of each other, these conventions can then get 
set 
> incompatib=
ly in different strains
> 
> These last two points define the difference be=
tween the two 
> approaches.  (1) defines all conventions in advance, which=
 means 
they 
> will always remain compatible, but limits some directions o=
f 
> growth.  (2) leaves some conventions unspecified, which allows any 
> =
valid direction of growth, but allows competing conventions to 
arise 
> in=
 different parts of the population.
> 
> A third approach, might be to leav=
e conventions undefined at 
first, 
> but then as soon as one individual de=
fines one, copy that 
restriction 
> across the whole population...
> 
>   =
       Ian
> 
> In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
> 
>
